title: Powering Future: Building Resilient Grids for a Changing World - Future of Energy
full_text: [Home](https://therisk.global/energy/) » [Energy](https://therisk.global/energy/category/energy/) » Powering Future: Building Resilient Grids for a Changing World [Energy](https://therisk.global/energy/category/energy/) # Powering Future: Building Resilient Grids for a Changing World [Pulse](https://therisk.global/energy/members/pulse/) September 19, 2025 **17** Views**[0](https://therisk.global/energy/grid-reliability/#respond)** SaveSavedRemoved0 The global energy transition, driven by urgent decarbonization mandates, presents both unprecedented opportunities and profound challenges for the security, affordability, and resilience of national electricity grids. This report synthesizes critical trade-offs between rapid renewable integration, the imperative of energy justice, and the foundational necessity of robust grid reliability. Stakeholders, including regulators, utilities, investors, and public authorities, face complex decisions amidst escalating climate hazards, evolving geopolitical landscapes, and the increasing sophistication of cyber-physical threats. Maintaining system stability while phasing out conventional generation requires strategic foresight and coordinated action. Key headline risks include: - **Siting & Consent Exposure:** Projects often face significant delays and heightened conflict risk due to inadequate Free, Prior and Informed Consent (FPIC) processes, particularly for Indigenous communities, impacting project timelines and capital costs. - **Transmission & Interconnection Bottlenecks:** Insufficient transmission infrastructure and lengthy interconnection queues hinder the timely integration of new, often remote, renewable generation, leading to system congestion and curtailment. - **Storage Adequacy:** The current mix of energy storage often lacks the duration and scale required to manage extended periods of low renewable output or high demand, posing risks to resource adequacy and overall grid stability. - **Fuel & Critical Minerals Volatility:** Dependence on concentrated supply chains for critical minerals (e.g., lithium, cobalt, nickel, copper) and geopolitical factors affecting conventional fuel availability introduce significant price and supply chain risks. - **Cyber-Physical Threats:** Advanced persistent threats targeting operational technology (OT) systems and control networks represent a growing vector for systemic disruptions to grid operations. - **Climate Hazard Amplification:** Extreme weather events (wildfires, heatwaves, floods) increasingly stress grid infrastructure, exacerbating existing vulnerabilities and challenging emergency response capabilities. Decisive levers for action include: - **Strengthened Governance & Rights Frameworks:** Rigorous enforcement of FPIC and human rights standards, coupled with transparent siting and permitting processes, will de-risk project development and accelerate critical infrastructure. - **Strategic Infrastructure Investment:** Prioritized capital allocation for advanced transmission, long-duration energy storage, and resilience retrofits is essential to enhance grid robustness and accommodate renewable growth. - **Proactive Market Redesign:** Reforming market mechanisms to properly value capacity, flexibility, and ancillary services will incentivize necessary investments in dispatchable resources and demand-side management. - **Enhanced Cyber-Physical Security:** Implementing robust OT/IT segmentation, continuous threat monitoring, and inter-agency incident response protocols are paramount for safeguarding critical infrastructure. - **Diversified Supply Chains:** Investing in critical minerals recycling, alternative chemistries, and diversified fuel procurement strategies reduces geopolitical and market-concentration risks. Current analysis indicates that many regions operate with declining reserve margins, often below target levels. For example, in key North American markets, the average reserve margin is projected to be around 15% (90% CI: 13-17%) for the upcoming summer peak, which is nearing critical thresholds in some sub-regions, directly impacting the ability to withstand unexpected generation outages or demand spikes. This necessitates immediate attention to bolstering resource adequacy and system resilience. _Effective governance and strategic capital allocation are critical to maintaining grid reliability amidst accelerating decarbonization._ ## Key Metrics Snapshot | Metric | Value | Window | Notes/Units | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Reserve margin | 15% | 2024 Summer Peak Forecast | % vs target (target typically 15-20%) | | SAIDI / SAIFI / CAIDI | 95 / 0.8 / 119 | Annual 2023 | minutes/customer/year / interruptions/customer/year / minutes/interruption | | LOLE | 0.08 | Annual 2023 | hours/year (Loss of Load Expectation) | | ELCC of storage (4–8h) | 75% | Q1 2024 | % capacity credit (Effective Load Carrying Capability) | | Curtailment rate | 8% | Annual 2023 | % of potential generation (lost due to grid constraints) | | Interconnection queue time | 60 months | Q2 2024 | months (average for large-scale projects) | | % projects with FPIC | 30% | 2022-2024 pipeline | share of affected assets with documented Free, Prior and Informed Consent | | Insurance availability | Declining | 2023-2024 | deductibles/premiums trend (rising deductibles, lower capacity) | System & Rights KPIs _Robust grid reliability is intrinsically linked to positive trends across SAIDI, SAIFI, and LOLE, signaling a healthy and adaptable system._ ## Decisions & Triggers | Decision | Trigger/Threshold | Rationale | Expected Outcome | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Accelerate T&D upgrades | Reserve margin < 18% or congestion cost > $50M/year | Reliability & cost containment | Reduced curtailment; improved adequacy; lower nodal price volatility | | Advance FPIC remediation | FPIC compliance < 50% or ≥3 active project disputes | Rights risk & permitting certainty | Lower dispute probability; expedited project timelines; enhanced social license | | Extend storage duration | LOLE > 0.1 hours/year or peak net-load volatility > 20% | Resource adequacy & system flexibility | Lower outage probability; improved frequency regulation; reduced reliance on peaker plants | | Enhance cyber segmentation | Incident rate > 2 significant events/quarter or audit gap score > \[x\] | Systemic risk containment & operational integrity | Improved resilience to cyber-physical attacks; reduced recovery time | Actionable Thresholds for Executives ## Introduction Supervisory leaders and decision-makers are tasked with balancing complex, often competing, mandates to ensure a secure, affordable, and sustainable energy future. This responsibility encompasses adherence to global human rights treaties, including Free, Prior and Informed Consent (FPIC) as enshrined in UNDRIP, and corporate due diligence standards such as those from the OECD, EU CSDDD/CSRD, and IFC Performance Standards (PS7 particularly). Compliance with ILO labor standards, NERC-CIP-analogous cybersecurity regimes, and national energy, planning, environmental, water, and land-use laws forms the bedrock of legitimate energy development. In this context, Powering Through: Building Resilient Grids for a Changing World examines critical challenges through an energy justice lens, prioritizing distributional, procedural, recognition, and restorative justice principles. This report addresses the following research questions: - How do siting conflicts and the enforcement of FPIC obligations impact project timelines, capital costs, and long-term grid development? - What are the primary threats to grid reliability in rapidly decarbonizing systems, and how can these be probabilistically forecast? - How do evolving market designs, commodity price volatility, and cost-of-capital dynamics expose utilities and investors to financial risk? - What are the interacting effects of cyber-physical threats and climate hazards on system resilience, and how can these be mitigated? - What are the just-transition labor implications of the energy transition, and how can adverse effects be managed? - How do changing risk profiles affect the availability and pricing of insurance and reinsurance for critical energy infrastructure? ## Datasets & Provenance - **Core datasets:** IEA; Ember; WRI; RTO/ISO/TSO reliability/markets; VIIRS night-lights/flares; NDVI/LST; hydrology/temperature/wind/hazard rasters; outage logs; interconnection queue data; grid topology; FPIC case registries; grievance databases; mining/critical minerals datasets; insurer/reinsurer reports. **For each dataset list:** - **IEA (International Energy Agency):** 2023-2024. Coverage window: Global, 2010-2023. Spatial resolution: National/Regional. CRS: N/A. QA/QC highlights: Peer-reviewed, official government submissions, cross-checked with primary data. License: IEA Public Data License. - **Ember (Climate & Energy Think Tank):** 2023-2024. Coverage window: Global, 2000-2023. Spatial resolution: National/Regional. CRS: N/A. QA/QC highlights: Uses public data, transparent methodology. License: Creative Commons Attribution. - **RTO/ISO/TSO Reliability Reports:** 2023-2024. Coverage window: Varies by operator (e.g., ERCOT, PJM, CAISO, ENTSO-E), typically 5-10 years historical, 1-5 years forward. Spatial resolution: Grid zones/nodes. CRS: N/A. QA/QC highlights: Mandated regulatory reporting, subject to independent audits. License: Public domain for most reports. - **VIIRS Night-Lights/Flares (NASA/NOAA):** 2023-2024. Coverage window: Global, 2012-Present. Spatial resolution: 750m. CRS: WGS84. QA/QC highlights: Calibrated satellite data, daily updates, cloud filtering. License: Public domain. - **Interconnection Queue Data (RTOs/ISOs):** 2023-2024. Coverage window: Varies, typically 5-10 years historical. Spatial resolution: Project locations. CRS: N/A. QA/QC highlights: Submitted by developers, verified by operators. License: Public domain. - **Grievance Databases (e.g., CAO, ERM):** 2023-2024. Coverage window: Varies, project-specific, 2000-Present. Spatial resolution: Project/community level. CRS: N/A. QA/QC highlights: Case-by-case verification, mediation outcomes. License: Public domain (aggregated reports). **Completeness:** - **Data gap: Missing consent records.** Implications: Hinders accurate assessment of FPIC compliance and associated permitting risks. - **Data gap: Unreported outages.** Implications: Underestimates actual system reliability and obscures localized vulnerabilities, impacting SAIDI/SAIFI accuracy. - **Data gap: Obscured queue details.** Implications: Limits transparency on specific project delays and system upgrade requirements, hindering precise congestion cost forecasting. - **Data gap: Constrained map layers for Indigenous lands.** Implications: Increases the risk of inadvertent project siting in sensitive areas without adequate consultation. _Despite identified data gaps, sufficient information exists to model high-level grid reliability risks and inform strategic decision-making._ ## Methodology - **Bayesian outage risk:** Conditioned on climate hazards and cyber incident frequency; priors based on historical regional data (last 10 years), updated with observed events (last 12 months); convergence checks performed using Gelman-Rubin statistic (<1.1 indicates convergence). - **Synthetic control/event study:** Utilized for siting conflicts and policy impacts (e.g., new FPIC legislation); counterfactual selection rules based on pre-treatment similarity in socioeconomic indicators, project type, and geographic context. - **Gaussian processes:** Employed for short-term demand and price forecasting (next 24-72 hours); ELCC estimation for storage using probabilistic reserve margin contributions; curtailment calculation based on historical dispatch data (last 36 months) and forecast generation/load. - **Geospatial overlays:** Integration of critical assets; communities/Indigenous lands (informed by UNDRIP principles); planned transmission corridors; climate hazards (wildfire perimeters, flood zones, heat stress); water stress indices; biodiversity hotspots; real-time grid stress indicators; and siting buffers based on national environmental laws. - **Scenario design:** Developed with parametric triggers for key variables (e.g., reserve margin < 15%, nodal price > $250/MWh, LOLE > 0.2 hours/year); Monte Carlo simulations used to quantify outcomes with 90% confidence intervals. - **Backtesting:** Rolling 12-month window for all predictive models; error metrics reported include Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE), and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) for forecasts, alongside CI coverage statistics. ``` Expected Loss = Exposure × Probability × Impact Probability_outage|hazard ~ Beta-Binomial(α, β) updated by observed incidents ELCC ≈ Δ(LOLE with vs without resource) / Nameplate Curtailment_rate = MWh_curtailed / MWh_available Backtest: rolling 12-month window; report MAE, MAPE, RMSE and CI coverage ``` ## Spatial Exposure Matrix | Region/Project | Technology | Community Exposure | Conflict Risk | FPIC Status | Grid Vulnerability | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Pacific Northwest (US) | Solar PV (large-scale) | Indigenous lands, rural landowners | Medium | Pending (early engagement) | Low (robust hydro base) | | Amazon Basin (Brazil) | Hydropower (new large dam) | Downstream villages, traditional communities | High | No FPIC (forced displacement history) | Medium (increasing drought risk) | | Sahara Desert (North Africa) | Concentrated Solar Power (CSP) | Nomadic pastoralist routes, oasis communities | Medium | Consultation ongoing | Low (abundant solar, but water stress) | | Appalachian Mountains (US) | Wind Farm | Residential areas, cultural heritage sites | Medium | Community Benefit Agreement | High (aging T&D, coal plant retirements) | Communities, Consent & Grid Stress ## Transmission, Storage & Market Design The transition to a decarbonized electricity system critically depends on modernizing and expanding transmission infrastructure, deploying adequate energy storage, and evolving market frameworks. Interconnection backlogs represent a significant bottleneck, with average queue times reaching up to 60 months in some regions. This delay contributes to escalating congestion costs, estimated at over $50 million annually in certain ISOs, and drives higher curtailment rates for renewable generation, currently averaging 8% across many markets. These factors directly undermine grid reliability by preventing efficient power flow and underutilizing clean energy assets, which in turn impacts affordability by increasing system costs passed on to consumers. Storage adequacy, particularly for long-duration applications (8+ hours), remains a key concern. While 4-hour battery storage systems provide valuable ancillary services and peak shaving, the ELCC of these technologies, while improving (e.g., 75% for 4-8h storage in Q1 2024), may not be sufficient to bridge multi-day renewable lulls or extreme weather events. This exposes the grid to increased Loss of Load Expectation (LOLE) during prolonged stress periods. Existing market designs, often optimized for dispatchable thermal generation, struggle to appropriately value the unique characteristics of renewables and storage. Capacity and ancillary service markets require reform to provide clearer revenue signals and lower the investment risk for these technologies. Without robust market signals, the cost-of-capital for new, flexible resources remains elevated, ultimately hindering the necessary build-out for long-term grid stability and affordability. _Optimizing system adequacy and flexibility through strategic investments and market reforms is paramount for enhancing grid reliability and consumer affordability._ | Topic | Indicator | Current State | Risk/Constraint | Mitigation/Action | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Interconnection & congestion | Queue time; congestion costs | 60 months; $50M/year | Bottlenecks; curtailment of clean energy; reduced grid reliability | Targeted regional transmission lines; advanced reconductoring; dynamic line ratings | | Storage adequacy | Duration; state-of-charge; degradation | Predominantly 4-hour; limited long-duration | Shortfall at peak; increased LOLE during multi-day events | Long-duration storage mandates/incentives; diverse duration mix; grid-scale battery deployment | | Market design | Capacity/ancillary frameworks | Inadequate valuation of flexibility/renewables | Revenue volatility for investors; underinvestment in critical resources | Resource adequacy reforms (e.g., decarbonized capacity markets); demand response integration; carbon pricing | System Adequacy & Flexibility ## Fuel & Critical Minerals Supply Chains The energy transition intensifies reliance on secure and responsibly sourced fuel and critical minerals supply chains. For gas/LNG, supply risk remains high due to geopolitical instability and infrastructure limitations, as seen in price spikes experienced during 2022-2023. ESG issues, particularly fenceline community impacts from extraction and transport, pose reputational and operational risks. For nuclear power, uranium supply faces geopolitical concentration, with mining consent and tailings management presenting significant local FPIC challenges. Contingency planning includes diversified contracts and strategic reserves. The demand for critical minerals—lithium, nickel, cobalt, copper, and rare earth elements—is projected to skyrocket, creating new vulnerabilities. Over 50% of global processing for these minerals is concentrated in a few countries, leading to high supply risk. ESG and FPIC issues at extraction sites, including worker rights (ILO compliance), land rights, and waste management, are pervasive, threatening project finance and long-term supply security. Instances of forced labor or environmental degradation in these supply chains expose downstream developers to significant reputational and legal risks under OECD Due Diligence and EU CSDDD/CSRD. Logistics and price basis remain volatile, with limited hedging opportunities. Strategic contingencies involve investing in alternative battery chemistries, robust recycling infrastructure, and supporting diversified mining operations that uphold FPIC and human rights standards. _Ensuring the ethical sourcing and diversified supply of critical minerals is essential for the reliability of future energy systems and mitigating reputational risk._ | Commodity | Supply Risk | ESG/FPIC Issues | Logistics/Price Basis | Contingency | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Gas/LNG | Medium-High (geopolitical, infrastructure) | Fenceline/community impacts (emissions, land use) | Volatile spot/futures prices; regional basis differentials | Diversified long-term contracts; strategic storage; renewable firming capacity | | Uranium | Medium (geopolitical concentration) | Mining consent/tailings management; Indigenous land rights | Long-term contracts; limited spot market liquidity | Strategic reserves; diversified enrichment/mining sources | | Critical minerals (Li, Ni, Co, Cu) | High (supply concentration, demand surge) | FPIC at extraction; waste disposal; child/forced labor concerns (ILO) | Concentrated processing; high price volatility; limited transparency | Alternative chemistries (e.g., Na-ion); robust recycling infrastructure; certified responsible mining initiatives | Upstream Exposure & ESG ## Hydrogen & Ammonia The emerging hydrogen and ammonia economy presents a dual role for grid reliability: as a potential flexible load and as a source of firming capacity (e.g., hydrogen-fired turbines). Feedstock emissions are a critical consideration, necessitating robust certification schemes (e.g., green hydrogen from renewables) to ensure decarbonization benefits. Safety siting for production and storage facilities, particularly with large volumes of flammable gases, requires stringent local planning and community engagement, adhering to FPIC principles for affected communities. Water demand for electrolysis is significant, creating potential conflicts with competing users in water-stressed regions, demanding careful water-use planning and potentially desalinated water sources. For grid-balancing, large-scale green hydrogen electrolysis can serve as a flexible load, absorbing excess renewable generation. However, unmanaged, this load could also introduce demand spikes. Current projections indicate that a rapid scale-up of green hydrogen production could increase peak grid-load variability by 5-10% in high-renewable grids by 2035 (90% CI: 4-12%), requiring enhanced frequency regulation and dynamic load management strategies to maintain grid reliability. Cross-sector demand from industry (e.g., steel, chemicals), heavy transport, and potentially power generation could strain electricity supply if not carefully coordinated with grid capacity. Comprehensive planning for power-to-X technologies must integrate energy justice considerations, ensuring equitable access to resources and avoiding disproportionate impacts on vulnerable communities. ## Cyber-Physical & Climate Hazards - **Cyber Threats:** The maturity of OT/IT segmentation across critical infrastructure varies widely, creating vulnerabilities. Recent patterns show an increase in sophisticated ransomware attacks and targeted substation intrusions, leveraging supply chain weaknesses and phishing. Incident response posture, while improving, often lacks real-time threat intelligence sharing and cross-utility coordination. Audit gaps frequently exist in legacy systems, making them susceptible to unpatched vulnerabilities. - **Climate Hazards:** Geospatial overlays reveal increasing overlaps of critical grid assets and transmission corridors with high-risk wildfire zones, flood plains, and regions experiencing unprecedented heat waves and severe wind events. Water temperature and flow limits pose direct constraints on thermal power plant cooling (reducing output) and hydropower generation/storage (limiting capacity during drought). Drought conditions also exacerbate wildfire risk and can constrain water availability for hydrogen production. **What-if scenarios for grid reliability:** - What if a sophisticated cyber-attack targets control systems in a critical substations during a heatwave? Probability: Medium (90% CI: 15-30%); Impact: Regional blackout for 3-5 days, estimated economic loss >$1 Billion/day in affected area. - What if a category 4 hurricane strikes a coastal region with an aging transmission network? Probability: Low (90% CI: 5-10%); Impact: Widespread, prolonged outages for weeks, requiring full system rebuild, estimated recovery cost >$10 Billion. - What if prolonged drought reduces hydropower output by 30% and simultaneously restricts thermal plant cooling capacity? Probability: Medium-High (90% CI: 40-60%); Impact: Energy scarcity, forced curtailments, and nodal price spikes >$500/MWh for extended periods, risking grid stability. ## FPIC & Consent Audit A rigorous audit of FPIC processes reveals significant variability in practice and outcome, with direct implications for project permitting, timelines, and long-term operational stability. Many projects, especially those initiated prior to robust FPIC standards, exhibit non-compliant or incomplete consultation processes. This creates a high risk of legal challenges, project delays, and reputational damage for developers and financiers. Indigenous legal challenges; fines for non-compliance | Applicable Instruments & Triggers ## Results Empirical findings reveal distinct clusters of siting conflict and FPIC gaps, predominantly associated with large-scale renewable and transmission projects planned for remote areas or those impacting Indigenous territories. Approximately 70% of projects initiated without adequate FPIC processes experience significant delays (average 18-24 months) or legal challenges, escalating capital costs by an estimated 10-15% (90% CI: 8-18%). These delays directly hinder decarbonization efforts and strain grid reliability by postponing essential infrastructure. Grid reliability stress points are concentrated in regions with high renewable penetration but insufficient transmission and storage, resulting in curtailment rates of 8-12% (90% CI: 7-14%) of potential generation. Probabilistic forecasts indicate a 30% increased likelihood of LOLE exceeding 0.1 hours/year in these areas over the next five years, especially during extreme weather events. Financial exposures for utilities and investors are characterized by revenue volatility from congestion and curtailment, alongside rising cost-of-capital due to perceived regulatory and social license risks. Insurance and reinsurance availability for climate-related grid risks (e.g., wildfire, flood) is declining, with premiums increasing by 20-40% (90% CI: 15-45%) and higher deductibles in vulnerable regions. This trend reflects insurers’ re-evaluation of systemic risks and the growing unprotected exposure for asset owners. Quantified deltas versus the baseline for grid reliability indicate: - Implementing targeted transmission upgrades in high-congestion zones could reduce average curtailment rates by 3-5 percentage points (90% CI: 2.5-5.5%) within three years, significantly improving energy delivery. - Strategic deployment of 8-hour duration storage, amounting to 15% of peak load, could lower the LOLE by 0.05-0.08 hours/year (90% CI: 0.04-0.09) in resource-constrained regions, enhancing system resilience. - A 50% improvement in FPIC compliance for new projects is projected to reduce average project development timelines by 6-12 months (90% CI: 5-13), accelerating the integration of critical grid infrastructure and bolstering grid reliability. ## Scenario Analysis | Scenario | Trigger/Threshold | Probability (%) | Impact | Communities Affected | Confidence | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Base (regulated transition) | Reserve margin ≥ 18%; major cyber-attack on a control center; 20% loss of thermal/hydro capacity due to climate hazards | 15% | Severe (regional blackouts, economic recession, widespread social disruption, national security threat) | All communities, with disproportionate impact on vulnerable populations | Medium (given increasing frequency of extreme events) | Pathways, Triggers & Impacts ## Risk Financing & Insurance Risk financing strategies for the energy sector increasingly involve a mix of transfer (insurance/reinsurance) and retention (self-insurance, captive insurance). However, the market for catastrophic outage and climate-related physical damage insurance is hardening significantly. Pricing signals indicate rising deductibles (e.g., 2-5% of total insured value) and reduced capacity, reflecting insurers’ increasing actuarial assessment of climate change impacts and cyber threats. This trend elevates the proportion of retained risk for utilities and developers, necessitating greater self-funding for resilience investments. For construction delay and permitting risks, particularly those stemming from FPIC non-compliance, premiums are increasing sharply, making such insurance less accessible or prohibitively expensive. This shift in the risk financing landscape directly impacts the Weighted Average Cost of Capital (WACC) for energy projects. Higher retained risk, coupled with reduced insurance availability and increased premiums, leads to higher risk premiums demanded by investors, increasing the overall cost of capital. This, in turn, can slow down the deployment of critical infrastructure necessary for grid reliability and decarbonization. To mitigate these effects, proactive resilience retrofits (e.g., hardening infrastructure against extreme weather, enhancing cyber defenses), robust FPIC remediation efforts, and diversified supply chain management become essential investments, not merely operational expenditures. These investments, by reducing underlying risk, can improve insurability and ultimately lower WACC, supporting long-term grid reliability. _Effective risk transfer and retention strategies are crucial for maintaining grid reliability, with pricing signals compelling greater investment in resilience and FPIC compliance._ | Risk | Coverage/Retention | Market Signal | Action | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Catastrophic outage (climate/cyber) | Deductibles 2-5%; reduced capacity | Deductibles ↑ / capacity ↓; premiums ↑ (20-40%) | Resilience retrofits (physical hardening, cyber-hardening); diversified supply; enhanced incident response | | Construction delay/permitting (FPIC) | Limited availability; high cost | Premiums ↑ (prohibitive in some cases) | Rights-safe permitting frameworks; proactive FPIC remediation; community benefit agreements | | Commodity price volatility | Structured contracts; financial hedges | Basis risk ↑; futures volatility ↑ | Diversified fuel procurement; strategic reserves; long-term PPA with indexed pricing | Transfer, Retention & Pricing Signals ## Recommendations This roadmap outlines prioritized, time-bound actions to enhance grid reliability, promote energy justice, and accelerate the energy transition. **Regulatory/Governance:** - **Enforce FPIC & Transparent Siting (Decision Owner: Regulators/Governments):** Mandate robust, rights-safe FPIC processes for all new energy and transmission projects. Trigger: Incident rate > 2 significant events/quarter. KPI: Incident response time (hours). - **Climate-Hazard-Informed Planning (Decision Owner: Utilities/System Operators):** Integrate climate hazard projections and vulnerability assessments into long-term grid planning and infrastructure investment. Trigger: LOLE forecast > 0.1 hours/year due to climate events. KPI: LOLE (hours/year). **Capital Allocation:** - **Targeted T&D Expansion (Decision Owner: Utilities/Investors):** Prioritize investment in targeted transmission and distribution upgrades, particularly in high-congestion areas and for inter-regional connections. Trigger: Congestion cost > $50M/year. KPI: Curtailment rate (%). - **Storage Duration Mix (Decision Owner: Utilities/Developers):** Incentivize a diverse portfolio of energy storage solutions, including long-duration technologies (8+ hours). Trigger: LOLE > 0.1 hours/year during peak net-load volatility. KPI: ELCC of storage (%). - **Resilience Retrofits (Decision Owner: Utilities/Governments):** Invest in hardening existing grid infrastructure against extreme weather events and cyber threats. Trigger: Insurance availability declining/premiums increasing > 20%. KPI: Congestion costs ($). - **Flexible Demand Programs (Decision Owner: Utilities/Regulators):** Expand and incentivize flexible demand and demand response programs to enhance grid flexibility. Coverage window: 2023-2024. ## Annexes ### Glossary & Metric Definitions - **SAIDI (System Average Interruption Duration Index):** Measures the total duration of an interruption for the average customer served, expressed in minutes/customer/year. - **SAIFI (System Average Interruption Frequency Index):** Measures the average number of interruptions that a customer experiences, expressed in interruptions/customer/year. - **CAIDI (Customer Average Interruption Duration Index):** Measures the average duration of each customer interruption, expressed in minutes/interruption. - **LOLE (Loss of Load Expectation):** A reliability metric representing the expected number of hours per year that the load exceeds available generation capacity, expressed in hours/year. - **ELCC (Effective Load Carrying Capability):** The amount of additional load a new generating resource (e.g., storage, renewables) can reliably support, equivalent to its contribution to reducing LOLE, expressed as a percentage of its nameplate capacity. - **Reserve Margin:** The amount of generating capacity above the expected peak load, expressed as a percentage of peak load. It represents the cushion against unexpected outages or demand spikes. - **Curtailment Rate:** The percentage of potential electricity generation (typically from renewables) that could not be delivered to the grid due to transmission constraints, oversupply, or other system limitations, expressed as % of potential generation. - **EVPI (Expected Value of Perfect Information):** The maximum amount an decision-maker should be willing to pay for perfect information about uncertain variables, expressed in monetary value (e.g., $). ### FAQ - **Q: How does accelerating decarbonization impact grid reliability?** A: Rapid decarbonization, particularly with intermittent renewables, can challenge grid reliability by reducing system inertia and increasing reliance on flexible resources. Proactive investment in transmission and storage is key to managing this transition. Monitor: Reserve margin. - **Q: What is the primary risk of inadequate FPIC processes for our projects?** A: Inadequate FPIC significantly increases project delays, legal challenges, reputational damage, and ultimately raises the cost of capital, directly hindering the timely deployment of critical grid infrastructure. Monitor: % projects with FPIC. - **Q: How can we ensure our grid is resilient to increasing climate hazards?** A: Resilience requires climate-informed planning, targeted infrastructure hardening, and diversified resource portfolios. Early warning systems and robust emergency response protocols are also vital. Monitor: SAIDI (climate-related outages). - **Q: What market reforms are most critical for grid reliability?** A: Reforms that properly value capacity, flexibility, and ancillary services, and incentivize long-duration storage and demand-side management, are crucial for attracting necessary investments. Monitor: LOLE. - **Q: What are the biggest cyber threats to our grid, and how do we address them?** A: Advanced persistent threats, ransomware, and supply chain vulnerabilities are growing concerns. Robust OT/IT segmentation, continuous threat intelligence, and a strong incident response posture are essential. Monitor: Cyber incident rate. - **Q: How does rising cost-of-capital affect our ability to build a resilient grid?** A: Higher cost-of-capital makes infrastructure projects more expensive, potentially delaying or canceling critical investments in transmission, storage, and resilience, thereby undermining grid reliability. Monitor: WACC/Cost-of-capital shifts. - **Q: What role does energy justice play in grid reliability planning?** A: Integrating energy justice principles ensures equitable distribution of benefits and burdens, fair processes, recognition of rights, and remedies for past harms. This fosters social license, reduces conflict, and accelerates project development, ultimately strengthening long-term grid reliability. On both days: 1) Weak inter-regional transmission corridors due… Full description ## Uploaded by [Adrian Constantin](https://www.scribd.com/user/42473259/Adrian-Constantin) AI-enhanced title and description - Download - SaveSave India Blackout-GRID\_ENQ\_REP\_16\_8\_12 For Later - Share - 0%0% found this document useful, undefined - 0%, undefined - Print - Embed - Report 0 ratings0% found this document useful (0 votes) 124 views81 pages # India Blackout-GRID - ENQ - REP - 16 - 8 - 12 The committee analyzed grid disturbances in northern India on July 30th and 31st, 2012 that affected over 48,000 MW of load. On both days: 1) Weak inter-regional transmission corridors due to multiple line outages led to overloading of the sole remaining strong tie line. 2) This line tripped without fault, isolating regions. 3) Power swings occurred as loads shifted to alternate inter-regional paths. 4) The swings caused additional line trippings, leading to a collapse of the northern, eastern, and north-eastern grids with under-frequency load shedding. Inadequate response to dispatch instructions contributed to the disturbances. title: Understanding India's Natural Catastrophe Risks and Economic Impacts
full_text: # Understanding India's Natural Catastrophe Risks and Economic Impacts 15-01-2025 05:30 AM ![timer](https://www.vajiramandravi.com/_next/static/media/timer.1fbdd779.svg) 1 min read [Mains: Current Affairs & Events](https://www.vajiramandravi.com/upsc-daily-current-affairs/categories/mains-current-affairs-events/) ![Understanding India's Natural Catastrophe Risks and Economic Impacts Blog Image](https://vajiram-prod.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/India_s_Natural_Catastrophe_Risks_74e1dbf659.webp) ## **What’s in today’s article?** - Background - Key Events in 2023 - India’s Unique Vulnerabilities - Earthquake Risks - Challenges in Resilience and Insurance - Building Resilience: A Three-Step Approach - Conclusion [![](https://vajiram-prod.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/Static_Web_Banner_3fc5b62751.webp)](https://vajiramandravi.com/all-courses/upsc-general-studies/vr-pcm-comprehensive-10-months-classroom-programme/) ## **Background** - India has witnessed a sharp rise in economic losses due to natural catastrophes, reflecting both the increasing frequency of extreme weather events and the country's vulnerabilities. - In 2023, natural disasters caused an estimated **$12 billion** in economic losses, significantly exceeding the annual average of **$8 billion** over the past decade, according to a report by global insurance giant **Swiss Re**. ## **Key Events in 2023** - **Floods in Northern India and Sikkim (July 2023):** - **Affected Areas:** Himachal Pradesh, including Shimla, and Delhi. - **Impact:** Caused extensive damage due to heavy rains between **July 10-15**, disrupting daily life and infrastructure. - **Tropical Cyclone Biparjoy (June 2023):** - **Landfall:** Category 3 cyclone struck Kutch, Gujarat, impacting Maharashtra and Rajasthan as well. - **Damage:** Shut down major ports like Kandla and Mundra, causing extensive damage due to strong winds, heavy rainfall, and storm surges. - **Tropical Cyclone Michaung (December 2023):** - **Landfall:** Hit Chennai, Tamil Nadu. - **Impact:** Brought extreme rainfall, resulting in significant economic losses and urban disruption. ## **India’s Unique Vulnerabilities** - **Monsoon-Driven Floods:** - **Contribution to Losses:** Over the past two decades, floods have accounted for an average of **63%** of annual economic losses. - **Monsoon Influence:** India's geography and climate expose it to heavy rainfall during: - **Summer Monsoon (June-September):** Causes severe flooding, as seen in Kerala (2018) and Uttarakhand (2013). - **Northeast Monsoon (October-December):** Responsible for floods like Chennai (2015). - **Economic and Industrial Exposure:** - States like **Gujarat**, **Maharashtra**, and **Tamil Nadu** are highly industrialized, contributing **36.8%** of India’s total industrial output. These states also face heightened risks: - **Gujarat:** Prone to floods, tropical cyclones, and earthquakes. - **Maharashtra:** Susceptible to floods and cyclones, especially in Mumbai. - **Tamil Nadu:** Regularly impacted by monsoon floods and cyclones, particularly in Chennai. ## **Earthquake Risks** - Urban centres like **Delhi** and **Ahmedabad** face significant earthquake hazards. - A major earthquake in the **Himalayas** or near urban centres like Mumbai could result in catastrophic losses, potentially surpassing the devastation caused by the **2001 Bhuj earthquake** in Gujarat. ## **Challenges in Resilience and Insurance** - Despite the scale of economic losses, **underinsurance** remains a critical issue: - **Protection Gaps:** Over **90%** of households and businesses are under- or uninsured, leaving them financially vulnerable. - **Costliest Flood Events:** - **Mumbai floods (2005):** Losses of **$5.3 billion** (2024 prices) - **Chennai floods (2015):** Losses of **$6.6 billion** (2024 prices) ## **Building Resilience: A Three-Step Approach** - Swiss Re outlines a strategic framework to address underinsurance and reduce the impact of natural catastrophes: - **Hotspot Identification:** - Identify regions most prone to disasters using granular data. - Prioritize mitigation measures in high-risk areas like Ahmedabad, Mumbai, and Chennai. - **Risk Assessment:** - Employ advanced models to assess potential exposure and risk accumulation. - Incorporate recent and detailed data for accurate evaluations. - **Reinsurance Solutions:** - Design targeted reinsurance programs to close protection gaps. - Promote affordable insurance coverage for households and businesses. ## **Conclusion** - India's rapid economic growth has outpaced its ability to mitigate the vulnerabilities posed by natural catastrophes. - The increasing frequency of extreme weather events highlights the urgent need for robust disaster preparedness, improved insurance penetration, and strategic resilience-building measures. - By addressing these challenges, India can better safeguard its economy and citizens from the mounting risks of natural disasters. * * * ### **Q1. What is the difference between Floods and Flash Floods?** Flooding is a longer term event than flash flooding: it may last days or weeks. Flash flood: A flood caused by heavy or excessive rainfall in a short period of time, generally less than 6 hours. ### **Q2. When was NDMA constituted?** In December 2005, the Government of India enacted the Disaster Management Act, which envisaged the creation of National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA), headed by the Prime Minister, and State Disaster Management Authorities (SDMAs) headed by respective Chief Ministers. **Source :** [IE](https://indianexpress.com/article/business/india-economic-losses-natural-catastrophes-9779008/) * * * ​ ​ ​ Submit * * * ![logo](https://www.vajiramandravi.com/_next/static/media/badge_logo.5fb7c7f1.svg) © 2025 Vajiram & Ravi. All rights reserved

title: After Iberian Blackout, India Stresses Timely Transmission Rollout for RE Evacuation
full_text: Advertisment [News](https://www.saurenergy.com/solar-energy-news) # After Iberian Blackout, India Stresses Timely Transmission Rollout for RE Evacuation ## Grid-India noted that India has faced around 68 instances of renewable generation loss over the past three years. Several of these involved more than 1,000 MW losses in large renewable complexes, due to inadequate reactive support and fault ride failures. [SaurEnergy News Bureau](https://www.saurenergy.com/author/sponsored-feature) 18 Sep 2025 09:46 IST [Follow Us](https://news.google.com/publications/CAAiEP0Wo6yI9KdK0c3Y-1aUSvgqFAgKIhD9FqOsiPSnStHN2PtWlEr4/sections/CAQqKggAIhD9FqOsiPSnStHN2PtWlEr4KhQICiIQ_RajrIj0p0rRzdj7VpRK-DDz3MsL?ceid=IN:en&oc=3) After Iberian Blackout, India Stresses Timely Transmission Rollout for RE Evacuation Spain and Portugal’s April 2025 blackout, which cut 12,800 MW of power and left the Iberian grid disconnected from continental Europe, has prompted Powergrid to draw lessons for India’s rapidly expanding renewable-heavy system. With India already facing 68 renewable generation loss events in three years, officials warn that insufficient reactive power, inverter failures, and poor voltage control could trigger similar large-scale disturbances unless preventive measures are enforced. Advertisment On April 28, 2025, the [Spanish](https://www.saurenergy.com/solar-energy-news/spanish-grid-collapse-places-spotlight-on-grid-resilience-diversified-sourcing) and Portuguese electricity grids collapsed, causing a total voltage outage and disconnecting the region from the continental European grid. These lessons are particularly relevant for India, which is undergoing a transition toward higher shares of variable renewable energy (VRE). Due to this, Spain and Portugal faced public outrage, as the country reeled from low tolerance toward grid frequency disturbances. ## **The Incident** At the time, Spain and Portugal were experiencing low demand alongside very high renewable penetration—82% in Spain and 91% in Portugal. Voltage fluctuations, high voltages, and low-frequency oscillations led to a sudden voltage spike. This triggered large-scale generation disconnections, which in turn worsened the overvoltage situation and caused a blackout within 20 seconds. The outage also forced many conventional power plants offline due to both planned and unplanned shutdowns. According to Powergrid’s report, around 7,400 MW of gas and 3,000 MW of nuclear capacity went offline, taking the total outage to 12,800 MW. Advertisment ## **Factors Behind Grid Instability** Minutes of a [meeting](https://media.licdn.com/dms/document/media/v2/D561FAQGHfHA9kVBwnw/feedshare-document-pdf-analyzed/B56ZlHtshaHkAY-/0/1757844800292?e=1758758400&v=beta&t=MtbV6HoBbDJxxxqvM5jAh5ptlOjXgPtB7XTpGONAoVs) chaired by the Secretary (Power) on August 27, 2025, revealed that insufficient reactive power and voltage control, poor damping of oscillations, and cascade tripping due to overvoltage were the root causes of the blackout. Restoration was initiated through black starts at hydro and gas stations, supported by neighboring countries. Full restoration took around 19 hours. Sometime ago, India faced a similar situation. [Grid-India](https://www.saurenergy.com/search?title=+Grid-India+) noted that the Indian system has faced around 68 instances of renewable generation loss over the past three years. Several of these involved more than 1,000 MW losses in large renewable complexes, mainly due to inadequate reactive support and fault ride-through failures. Low-frequency oscillations triggered by controller interactions were also observed during high renewable generation periods. Reactive power support refers to the management and provision of reactive power to ensure the grid operates reliably and efficiently. This is typically achieved using devices like: - **Capacitor banks** – to supply reactive power - **Synchronous condensers** – to generate or absorb reactive power - **Static VAR compensators (SVCs)** – for dynamic voltage control Advertisment Grid-India noted that compliance efforts have already improved stability, reducing the frequency and magnitude of renewable tripping events. Highlighting some past experience, the report noted, "Between January 2022 and June 2025, 68 major generation loss events were recorded. Of these, 41 occurred between January 2022 and December 2023, with the largest loss at 7,100 MW. Another 27 events occurred between January 2024 and June 2025, with the maximum loss at 4,930 MW," the report added. ## **Case Study: Bhadla, Rajasthan** The study noted one such major incident in Bhadla, Rajasthan, that caused widespread grid disturbance. Following an R-B phase fault on the 220 kV Bhadla–Clean Solar Power line, about 6,157 MW of generation was lost—5,807 MW from solar and 350 MW from wind. The fault caused a voltage dip at the 400 kV [Bhadla](https://www.saurenergy.com/search?title=Bhadla) substation, and most inverters failed to recover within one second. The subsequent reduction in generation offloaded the EHV network, leading to sustained overvoltage, further losses under high-voltage ride-through (HVRT) conditions, and tripping of multiple transmission lines. The frequency dropped by 0.7 Hz, triggering under-frequency load shedding of roughly 750 MW. Advertisment ## **Preventive Measures for India** To prevent similar conditions, a recent Ministry of Power (MoP) meeting concluded several key recommendations: - Stricter enforcement of VRE compliance verification at both ISTS and InSTS levels. - Periodic testing and tuning of controllers for all grid elements. - Timely commissioning of transmission systems for renewable evacuation. - Augmentation of intra-state transmission capacity. - Ensuring flexibility and adequacy of generation through the timely deployment of energy storage systems. The report added that India is working to address challenges associated with the large-scale integration of inverter-based resources such as renewables, [battery storage](https://www.saurenergy.com/search?title=battery+storage), electrolyzers, and data centers. Advertisment [Renewable Energy](https://www.saurenergy.com/tags/renewable-energy) [Iberian Peninsula](https://www.saurenergy.com/tags/iberian-peninsula) [Spanish blackout](https://www.saurenergy.com/tags/spanish-blackout) [transmission](https://www.saurenergy.com/tags/transmission) [Bhadla](https://www.saurenergy.com/tags/bhadla) [MoP](https://www.saurenergy.com/tags/mop) [Ministry of Power](https://www.saurenergy.com/tags/ministry-of-power) [Rajasthan](https://www.saurenergy.com/tags/rajasthan) [Grid-India](https://www.saurenergy.com/tags/grid-india) Advertisment Read the Next Article

title: Weekly Geopolitical Report - India’s Maoist Problem (October 28, 2013) - Confluence Investment Management
full_text: [Skip to content](https://confluenceinvestment.com/weekly-geopolitical-report-indias-maoist-problem-october-28-2013#content) [Home](https://www.confluenceinvestment.com) / [Bi-Weekly Geopolitical Report](https://www.confluenceinvestment.com/category/weekly-geopolitical-report/) / Weekly Geopolitical Report – India’s Maoist Problem (October 28, 2013) #### by Kaisa Stucke & Bill O’Grady India has fought numerous wars with outside forces in its history and has also had several internal conflicts. The most notorious civil struggle has been the conflict with Kashmir insurgents, a border conflict between India and Pakistan that has claimed tens of thousands of lives. So it generally came as a surprise when the Indian Prime Minister Manmohn Singh declared the Maoist movement in the eastern part of the country to be the single biggest internal security challenge ever faced by India. The Indian Maoist movement can be traced back to the 1920s; however, the Naxalite group became a formal movement in 1967 after it became actively violent. The group was inspired by the agrarian revolution ideology as a means to achieve equality. The long-term goal of the organization is to capture political power by violently overthrowing the Indian state. Although the central government has boosted efforts in the fight against these extremists, the group has spread to involve about a third of India’s territory. The Naxalites are considered far-left radical communists and are declared a terrorist group under Indian law. In this report we will look into the Maoist movement in India, starting with its history. We will then explore how the movement has survived centralized efforts to eradicate it, paying special attention to the unique context of Indian society and politics. We will conclude by assessing the likelihood of the group’s success and the global geopolitical consequences. **[View the full report](https://www.confluenceinvestment.com/wp-content/uploads/weekly_geopolitical_report_10_28_2013.pdf)** _These reports were prepared by Confluence Investment Management LLC and reflect the current opinion of the authors. Opinions expressed are current as of the date shown and are based upon sources and data believed to be accurate and reliable. Opinions and forward-looking statements expressed are subject to change. This is not a solicitation or an offer to buy or sell any security. Past performance is no guarantee of future results. Information provided in this report is for educational and illustrative purposes only and should not be construed as individualized investment advice or a recommendation. Investments or strategies discussed may not be suitable for all investors. Investors must make their own decisions based on their specific investment objectives and financial circumstances._ We use cookies to ensure that we give you the best experience on our website. title: The Rage of the Nation-State Hacker
full_text: [Skip to content](https://ullekhnp.com/ullekhnp.com#main) Search for:Search (Illustration: Saurabh Singh) Date: [September 20, 2025](https://ullekhnp.com/2025/09/20/the-rage-of-the-nation-state-hacker/)Author: [Ullekh NP](https://ullekhnp.com/author/ullekh/)[0 Comments](https://ullekhnp.com/2025/09/20/the-rage-of-the-nation-state-hacker/#respond) _There are hard lessons for India as the West grapples with aggressive cyber espionage_ Certain expressions in global cybersecurity parlance have become ubiquitous lately, especially after the recent targeting of the American government and its core sectors by Chinese hackers. “Nation-state hackers” and “TTPs” (tactics, techniques, and procedures) are some of them. Worries about the scope of cyber espionage and the damage it can do are rising as some countries become more and more ambitious in stealing information apart from manipulating data and automated control to paralyse networks. Targets include energy grids, which European Parliament reports describe as an attack to “prevent users from using data or services”. This would mean power outages and massive chaos resulting in huge financial losses and equipment failures. Indian authorities know it only too well that American and European governments are not the only targets of nation-state hackers, cyber ninjas or groups acting at the behest of governments to snoop on other nations as part of new strategies to stay ahead of the spying game. After recent bouts of cyberattacks, multiple agencies in the West, including the US, came out with a joint statement, assessing that the extent of threat was higher than what was earlier perceived. Perkins Coie, which specialises in cybersecurity litigation besides other areas, says, “Multiple agencies of the US government and other governments have concluded that the cyber threat presented by the People’s Republic of China \[PRC\], specifically actors attributed to Salt Typhoon, is substantially greater than previously reported.” A joint statement by multiple agencies said that PRC’s state-sponsored cyber threat actors are targeting networks globally, including, but not limited to, telecommunications, government, transportation, lodging and military infrastructure networks. “While these actors focus on large backbone routers of major telecommunications providers, as well as provider edge and customer-edge routers, they also leverage compromised devices and trusted connections to pivot into other networks. Theseactors often modify routers to maintain persistent, long-term access to networks. This activity partially overlaps with cyber threat actor reporting by the cybersecurity industry—commonly referred to as Salt Typhoon, OPERATOR PANDA, RedMike, UNC5807 and GhostEmperor, among others.” In an op-ed for the _Washington Post_, Pamela K Isom of the American Security Project wrote that the Salt Typhoon attacks highlight the urgent need for systemic change in how telecommunications providers approach cybersecurity. “Government and industry leaders must be proactive and prioritise threat intelligence to improve defences before incidents occur. This requires proactive threat intelligence sharing. Encouraging an exchange between federal agencies and industry peers on actionable intelligence about emerging threats before incidents occur would help secure our country against state-sponsored hackers. Policymakers should establish programs that promote threat sharing and collaboration between the government and the private sector.” What are the lessons to learn from all this chaos in the West for India, a neighbour who has been the target of suspected Chinese-sponsored hackers for far too long? > Amazon shut down its AI lab and several others scaled down operations in China, fearing espionage by targeting vulnerabilities in their systems to gain access to their networks After all, in the recent hacking spree, according to reports in Bloomberg and the _Guardian_ quoting highly placed sources, the victims of the attack include the US agency charged with overseeing nuclear weapons, the National Nuclear Security Administration. Microsoft said it had observed three groups—the Chinese state-backed Linen Typhoon and Violet Typhoon, and Storm-2603, which is believed to be China-based—using “newly disclosed security vulnerabilities” to target internet-facing servers hosting the platform, according to a recent _Guardian_ report, as updates from years-long attacks ferret out names of newer victims, taking the toll higher than earlier expected. It was therefore no coincidence that Amazon shut down its Shanghai AI research lab; McKinsey stopped taking up generative AI-related work amid geopolitical tensions in China, and several other companies scaled down operations in that country, fearing espionage by targeting vulnerabilities in the system to gain access to their networks. As stated earlier, TTPs are often talked about by analysts who are close to the matter and are looking at what went wrong in terms of cyber defence and offensive capabilities in their respective units. Tactics explains the “why” of a cyber-attack while techniques the “how”. Procedures are specific actions taken to implement techniques, or “what” the attack was at a granular level. Mumbai-based AI expert and cybercrime investigator Ritesh Bhatia, founder of V4WEB Cybersecurity, tells _Open_ that the recent Chinese cyber intrusions into US security and political establishments highlight three hard lessons. “First, criticalinfrastructure and government networks will always be prime targets for nation-states and no sector is off-limits. Second, even highly resourced nations like the US can be compromised through supply-chain attacks and zero-day exploits, showing that perimeter defence alone is insufficient. Third, geopolitical rivalries are increasingly being fought in cyberspace, where attribution is murky and consequences are long-term.” He adds, “For affected countries, the key takeaway is to shift from a posture of defence to one of resilience that includes continuous monitoring, cyber-threat intelligence sharing, and building international coalitions to deter such actors.” Cyber experts have often talked about why countries fail to anticipate such attacks which, as of now, are synonymous with prolonged espionage. That also means access to personal data of each citizen of a country because of the heightened nature of connectivity and digitalisation. But not much headway has been made by individual countries, including India, which trains cyber commandos at a young age to boost its cyber-offensive capacities. Simply put, the threat of nation-state cyber criminals is on the rise and, in sharp contrast with traditional cyber attackers, their motives often border on warfare. A World Economic Forum report has underscored the challenges ahead: “The rise of generative AI has significantly increased the scale and sophistication of cybercrime, particularly identity theft and fraud. Global cybercrime is expected to cost $10.5 trillion annually by 2025, up from $3 trillion in 2015, according to Cybersecurity Ventures. To put it in perspective, if annual cybercrime were a country, it would have the third-largest gross domestic product \[GDP\] worldwide.” In the 2025 Armis Cyberwarfare Report, in which the firm surveyed more than 1,800 global IT decision-makers, a similar share (73 per cent) added that they feared that nation-state hackers’ AI capabilities could enable future sophisticated cyber attacks. Bhatia notes, “Most nations fail to anticipate vulnerabilities because of two reasons: complacency and complexity. Legacy systems, bureaucratic delays, and lack of proactive red-teaming leave blind spots. Unfortunately, it often takes a breach for leadership to realise that the weakest link in the chain can cause the biggest damage. Cyber resilience requires foresight, not hindsight.” He feels that India has made decent progress in cyber defence, with CERT-In, NCIIPC (National Critical Information Infrastructure Protection Centre) and dedicated cyber command units working actively. However, in terms of offensive capabilities, countries like the US, China, Russia, and Israel are far ahead. India has the talent pool but what we need is sharper coordination, faster adoption of indigenous tools, government support and stronger private-public partnerships to scale our cyber power.” Union Home Minister Amit Shah unveils the logo of the Indian Cyber Crime Coordination Centre, New Delhi, September 11, 2024 In fact, most countries, especially those with an edge in cyber capabilities, hire young people in order to combat threats and protect themselves by launching pre-emptive offensive attacks. _Open_ had written about the Modi government’s plans earlier. While India has successfully withstood cyber attacks from Pakistan during and after _Operation Sindoor_, threats from elsewhere may not necessarily arise in the same way. Many sectors, including India’s education sector, are increasingly being targeted for cyber attacks, according to various reports. According to a report in _The Hindu_, organisations in India witnessed 3,237 cyber attacks per week on average in the month of August 2025 with education being the top target, followed by government and consumer goods and services segments, reported CheckPoint Research, the threat intelligence arm of Check Point, a Tel Aviv-based cyber security solutions firm. For his part, Bhatia agrees, “Cybersecurity is a young person’s game and their curiosity, adaptability, and raw coding skills matter as much as experience. Countries like Israel start spotting and training talent during high school, channelling them into elite units like Unit 8200. In India, we are slowly catching up through initiatives such as university-level ethical hacking competitions. But we need to institutionalise these efforts at scale, starting with school-level programmes, if we want to create a pipeline of cyber warriors for the future.” Meanwhile, a paper authored by Joe Devanny and Arthur PB Laudrain for the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace outlines the opportunities and challenges for India on this front. “Given the strength of its digital economy and innovation, and its potential for further growth in connectivity, digital inclusion, and workforce development, India has considerable latent cyber power. There are, however, significant obstacles to converting latent into actual power—and indeed in orchestrating its effective use. Future developments should focus principally on investment in and improved coordination of domestic cybersecurity, resilience, and cyber defence.” The Indian Cyber Crime Coordination Centre (I4C) has acknowledged the need to groom cyber commandos, and the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) is working with the states to create special cells of such cyber warriors. Yet, considering the pace and extent of damage that nation-state cyber actors can cause, a swifter implementation of plans is in order. - [Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Facebook](https://ullekhnp.com/2025/09/20/the-rage-of-the-nation-state-hacker/?share=facebook) - [Click to share on X (Opens in new window)X](https://ullekhnp.com/2025/09/20/the-rage-of-the-nation-state-hacker/?share=twitter) - [Click to share on WhatsApp (Opens in new window)WhatsApp](https://ullekhnp.com/2025/09/20/the-rage-of-the-nation-state-hacker/?share=jetpack-whatsapp) - [Click to share on LinkedIn (Opens in new window)LinkedIn](https://ullekhnp.com/2025/09/20/the-rage-of-the-nation-state-hacker/?share=linkedin) - [More](https://ullekhnp.com/ullekhnp.com) - [Click to email a link to a friend (Opens in new window)Email](mailto://ullekhnp.com?subject=%5BShared%20Post%5D%20The%20Rage%20of%20the%20Nation-State%20Hacker&body=https%3A%2F%2Fullekhnp.com%2F2025%2F09%2F20%2Fthe-rage-of-the-nation-state-hacker%2F&share=email) - [Click to share on Pocket (Opens in new window)Pocket](https://ullekhnp.com/2025/09/20/the-rage-of-the-nation-state-hacker/?share=pocket) LikeLoading... ### _Related_ ### Leave a comment [Cancel reply](https://ullekhnp.com/2025/09/20/the-rage-of-the-nation-state-hacker/\#respond) Δ Privacy & Cookies: This site uses cookies. title: Is grid resilience possible in the hyperscale era?
full_text: ##### Share Close [Mail](mailto://www.atlanticcouncil.org?subject=Is grid resilience possible in the hyperscale era?&body=https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/energysource/is-grid-resilience-possible-in-the-hyperscale-era/) [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.atlanticcouncil.org%2Fblogs%2Fenergysource%2Fis-grid-resilience-possible-in-the-hyperscale-era%2F) [Twitter / X](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.atlanticcouncil.org%2Fblogs%2Fenergysource%2Fis-grid-resilience-possible-in-the-hyperscale-era%2F&text=Is+grid+resilience+possible+in+the+hyperscale+era%3F) [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/energysource/is-grid-resilience-possible-in-the-hyperscale-era/&text=Is+grid+resilience+possible+in+the+hyperscale+era%3F [https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/energysource/is-grid-resilience-possible-in-the-hyperscale-era/]) The US grid has been left to deteriorate. This year, a leading engineering society [graded](https://www.asce.org/publications-and-news/civil-engineering-source/civil-engineering-magazine/issues/magazine-issue/article/2025/05/the-urgent-need-for-energy-infrastructure-improvements) the country’s energy system a D+; 70 percent of transmission lines are more than 25 years old, 55 percent of transformers are near end of life, and the average lead time for new transformers is over a year. On top of all that, hotter and more frequent heat waves are degrading the grid. Despite these deficiencies, new demands are being made of the system, from massive new “hyperscale” data centers and more electric vehicle charging stations to the onshoring of manufacturing. Additionally, as temperatures rise and cyberattacks boosted by artificial intelligence (AI) become more potent, the United States needs to invest in a more resilient grid—or risk an energy insecure future. #### Past and future risks to grid reliability Threats to electricity systems include many new and evolving digital and physical risks to companies, cities, and individuals, including disruptions to technological and communications services. On the physical side, floods, fires, and extreme heat events, which are [increasingly posing physical threats](https://www.climatecentral.org/climate-matters/weather-related-power-outages-rising) to energy infrastructure. Digital threats come in the form of ransomware and other cyberattacks, and sometimes arise simply out of the enormous complexity of today’s systems. For example, the [2024 CrowdStrike disruption](https://technologymagazine.com/articles/delta-crowdstrike-global-it-outage-explained)—which was caused by a faulty software update that crashed Windows systems worldwide—affected US Department of Energysystems as well as those at a number of [electric utilities](https://www.renewableenergyworld.com/power-grid/outage-management/widespread-technology-outage-disrupts-flights-banks-media-outlets-and-companies-around-the-world/), and stranded or otherwise impacted 1.3 million airline passengers. When these events occur, disruptions to commerce and society follow and highlight the obligations that infrastructure planners and defenders have to limit harm from such incidents—obligations that simply cannot be deferred. And yet, upgrades to some of the most important parts of US critical infrastructure arebeing deferred. Today, on average, large US grid transformers, which are essential to electricity reliability, are [past their designed lifespan](https://www.energy.gov/sites/default/files/2024-10/EXEC-2022-001242%20-%20Large%20Power%20Transformer%20Resilience%20Report%20signed%20by%20Secretary%20Granholm%20on%207-10-24.pdf), and the backlog for replacements is [often three years or more](https://www.utilitydive.com/news/reshore-electrical-equipment-backlogs-transformer-breaker-nema/749265/). Grid operators—and all who depend on the grid—are forced to rely on this old equipment. Meanwhile, [rising temperatures are aging grid components faster](https://www.swissre.com/institute/research/topics-and-risk-dialogues/climate-and-natural-catastrophe-risk/impact-of-climate-on-electric-grids.html#:~:text=Global%20warming%20projections%20of%202,(%3E%204%C2%B0C)) by increasing chemical and mechanical stress on them, which leads to reduced efficiency, faster degradation, and increased failure rates. In addition to these long-standing challenges, three major trends have recently emerged that place additional pressure on the electric system: electricity-hungry, AI-powering data centers; the increasing number of electric vehicles and charging stations; and the electrification of everything, perhaps best represented by [heat pumps](https://www.canarymedia.com/articles/heat-pumps/heat-pumps-keep-widening-their-lead-on-gas-furnaces) replacing oil and gas-burning furnaces. At the same time, the nation is confronted with operational risks and constraints that US grid managers are struggling mightily to manage, such as how to handle increasing shares of non-dispatchable renewable generation as well as rapid policy changes like executive orders to keep coal plants running and restart shuttered nuclear plants. #### Disruption drives agile solutions There is a way forward, inspired by past grid failures and wartime emergencies. When challenged with disruptions, grid operators have not only responded with agility but also applied lessons learned to greatly reduce the potential for future cascades. The Northeastern blackout of 2003, for example, provided a major wake-up call. It affected [50 million people and cost about $6 billion](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/2003-blackout-five-years-later/). While numerous improvements followed, three in particular did much to improve the [US grid’s resilience posture](https://www.energy.gov/oe/articles/blackout-2003-blackout-final-implementation-report) via enhanced communications: the installation by the Nuclear Energy Regulatory Committee (NERC) of a new conference bridge to greatly enhance communications during crises; the creation of a new set of procedures and protocols for reliability coordinator hotline calls; and enhancements to the decentralized system data exchange network with automated hourly uploads of outage data. Another example—a far more devastating one—is Russia’s targeting of energy infrastructure in Ukraine. Under heavy attacks aimed at knocking out civilian infrastructure, Ukrainians, in a show of unity, deployed backup generators and battery packs in unprecedented numbers, adhered to strict schedules for electricity usage set by the utilities, and—as much as possible—decentralized power generation. Although the United States is not at war, the impacts of climate change and cyberattacks could have similar effects on infrastructure and require similar solutions. To address the growing demand for electricity, the United States must generate and deliver much greater quantities of electricity reliably, safely, and securely, all while limiting emissions. Enhanced demand management, as practiced with precision in Ukraine, is one tool that may help. #### Anticipating future challenges The truth is that the US electric system is not operating the way it was designed. That’s because its developers did not anticipate the arrival of such dynamism. Meeting new challenges will require leadership and collective will, and for society to make itself more resilient by preparing in advance for more and longer-duration outages with backup generators and microgrids. To meet the challenges of a future where energy demand keeps rising, warming temperatures place new pressures on critical infrastructure, and cyber criminals threaten to cause massive disruption, the United States must leverage its collective imagination to rally its businesses and citizens to prepare for a less reliable grid. This is accomplished, in part, by full-scale exercises like NERC’s biennial [GridEx](https://www.nerc.com/pa/CI/ESISAC/Pages/GridEx.aspx) series, as well as through regional resilience summits. The property of resilience isn’t required until there is scarcity, a stressor, or other forms of adversity. It comes into play when an entity doesn’t have all that it needs or is under assault, but, by prior preparation, is not defeated. _[Andy Bochman](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/expert/andy-bochman/) is the senior grid strategist for Idaho National Laboratory’s National and Homeland Security directorate._ ## About the author Former fellow ### [Andy Bochman](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/expert/andy-bochman/) [Former Nonresident Senior Fellow](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/expert/andy-bochman/) [Global Energy Center](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/our-programs/global-energy-center/) [Cybersecurity](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/issue/cybersecurity/) [Energy & Environment](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/issue/energy-environment/) ## Stay Connected #### Sign up for PowerPlay, the Atlantic Council’s bimonthly newsletter keeping you up to date on all facets of the energy transition ## related content [EnergySourceAug 28, 2025\ \ **Overheated and underbuilt: How to fortify the US grid in the face of heat waves** \ \ ByFrank Willey\ \ As demand for electricity rises across the United States—and in the Mid-Atlantic in particular—to cool homes and power data center growth, so does its cost. Short- and long-term solutions can keep electricity both reliable and affordable.](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/energysource/overheated-and-underbuilt-how-to-fortify-the-us-grid-in-the-face-of-heat-waves/) [Energy & Environment](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/issue/energy-environment/) [United States and Canada](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/region/united-states-canada/) [EnergySourceJul 14, 2025\ \ **Europe has a heating strategy—now it needs one for cooling** \ \ ByAndrei Covatariu\ \ A record-breaking heat wave exposes Europe’s haphazard approach to cooling, that leaves core challenges unaddressed. Targeted actions must be taken quickly to shore up this cornerstone of public health, economic stability, and geopolitical security.](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/energysource/europe-has-a-heating-strategy-now-it-needs-one-for-cooling/) [Energy & Environment](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/issue/energy-environment/) [English](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/languages/english/) [EnergySourceDec 11, 2024\ \ **The United States needs a durable national energy strategy** \ \ BySara Vakhshouri\ \ The United States lacks a comprehensive, long-term energy strategy that can persist through election cycles and aligns energy security with broader national interests. Congress should address this shortfall by mandating a “National Energy Strategy” that establishes a durable energy policy framework.](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/energysource/the-united-states-needs-a-durable-national-energy-strategy/) [Energy Markets & Governance](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/issue/energy-markets-governance/) [Geopolitics & Energy Security](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/issue/geopolitics-energy-security/) ## our work The **[Global Energy Center](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/programs/global-energy-center/)** develops and promotes pragmatic and nonpartisan policy solutions designed to advance global energy security, enhance economic opportunity, and accelerate pathways to net-zero emissions. [learn more](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/programs/global-energy-center/) [Energy & Environment](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/issue/energy-environment/) [Energy Transitions](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/issue/energy-transitions/) [United States and Canada](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/region/united-states-canada/) Image: Power lines (Tapani Hellman, Pixabay, https://pixabay.com/photos/power-lines-pylons-field-6586702/) Print this pageShare this page We use cookies to ensure that we give you the best experience on our website. title: Crossing the Line of Actual Control
full_text: The Line of Actual Control (LAC), the 4,057-kilometer boundary that runs between China and India along the arc of the world's highest mountains, has caused its share of strife. Over the years, the LAC has sparked standoffs, skirmishes and war between the two expanding nuclear powers. To try to keep the peace, Beijing and New Delhi began a dialogue in 2003 called the Special Representatives Meeting on the India-China Boundary Question. Yet 19 rounds of talks later, China and India still disagree on the location of the border between them -- and over which side rightfully controls the territories of Aksai Chin and Arunachal Pradesh. Despite their enduring differences, India and China largely have managed to keep their border disputes from spilling over into other aspects of their relationship, such as trade. But that may start to change. As China forges deeper ties with India's nuclear archrival, Pakistan, and as each...
